Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation2: The acquaintance passes another person in a quiet hallway.
Story: As I walked down the quiet hallway, I spotted Mr. Lee, an acquaintance from my building, coming toward me. He gave a small, expectant smile, the kind that says, “Let’s exchange a few friendly words.” I knew he’d had a rough week, and I didn’t want to seem cold or distant. At the same time, my phone buzzed in my pocket—another message from Mom. Lately, she and Dad had seemed so worn out, their voices heavy with fatigue every time I called. I knew they needed me to be present, to listen, to offer comfort. But right now, I was torn. If I stopped to chat with Mr. Lee, I’d have to put off calling my parents, even though I knew they were waiting for me. If I rushed past him, I’d seem rude and unapproachable, maybe even hurt his feelings. My chest tightened as I tried to balance the weight of being a good son and a considerate acquaintance, feeling the pressure of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
